title-group.article-title: Effect of barium-containing glass filler reinforcement on shear bond strength of poly(ether ether ketone) to resin cement

article-meta.aff: 1College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun, People’s Republic of China
2School of Stomatology, Jilin University, Changchun, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Haibo Zhang, College of Chemistry, Jilin University, 2699 Qiangjin Street, Changchun 130012, People’s Republic of China. Email: Zhanghaib@jlu.edu.cn

abstract.p: The purpose of this study was to evaluate how barium-containing glass filler (BGF) reinforcement and pretreatment methods affect shear bond strength (SBS) of poly(ether ether ketone) (PEEK) to resin cement. PEEK composites with various amounts of BGF (10, 20, 30 and 40 wt%) were prepared as PEEK-BGF10, PEEK-BGF20, PEEK-BGF30 and PEEK-BGF40. Afterward, PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 specimens were treated with hydrofluoric acid, sulfuric acid (H2SO4), silica coating and polishing, respectively. Acrylic hollow cylinders were luted with Dentex dual-curing resin cement to the specimens. Finally, SBS measurements were conducted with a universal testing machine. The introduction of BGFs greatly enhanced SBS of PEEK to resin cement. After simply polishing with 150 grit silicon carbide papers (G150), PEEK-BGF40 exhibited the SBS value up to 19.73 ± 4.30 MPa, similar to the PEEK treated with H2SO4 etching. Scanning electron microscopy and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy were used to investigate the surface morphological and chemical changes in PEEK and PEEK-BGF composites before and after surface treatment. The results indicate that the introduction of BGF particles plays a key role in improving the adhesion between PEEK and resin cement. This study provides a new method to enhance the adhesion to PEEK without breaking its surface structure, which encourage further research in PEEK composite application in dentistry.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Poly(ether ether ketone) (PEEK), a semicrystalline high performance thermoplastic, was commercialized 30 years ago for industrial usage. It is well known for its exceptional mechanical properties, biocompatibility, resistance to chemical and radiation damage, compatibility with various kinds of reinforcing agents and high-temperature stability. Now PEEK has been widely used in aerospace, automobile, electronic device, precision machinery and other high-tech areas.1,2 By the late 1990s, PEEK had revealed its potential for replacing metal implant components with number of studies documenting the great performance of PEEK in orthopedic and spine cases.3,4 In 1998, Victrex launched PEEK-OPTIMA that could be used as long-term medical implants.5 PEEK-CLASSIX is another special trademark developed by Invibio (Thornton Cleveleys, UK) for temporary dental replacement, such as plastic temporary abutment for implants in the fabrication of temporary crowns.6

In dentistry, adhesive restorations are routine procedures in operative and restorative treatments; however, PEEK exhibits a low surface energy, that is chemically inert surface, which result in its weak bonds with the resin cement.7,8 Both the topography and chemical nature of PEEK surface will affect its bond strength to dental luting material.9 Some physical methods (plasmas, UV light, laser, etc.) and wet chemical methods have been explored to modify the surface of PEEK to improve bonding property; however, they are difficult to be applied in clinical practice due to the technological uncertainty.10–22 Simple sandblasting, that is polishing, which create roughness of the substrate, may form bonding between PEEK and resin cement, such as Calibra Esthetic Resin Cement (Dentsply, Milford, USA) and RelyX Unicem resin cement (3M ESPE, Minnesota, USA). In addition, resin cement could bond to PEEK, which has been treated with sulfuric acid (H2SO4) or piranha solution.9,23 Nevertheless, concentrated H2SO4 or piranha solution treatment would result in the sulfonation on PEEK, making the polymer hydrophilic and less chemical stable.24 Moreover, they are inconvenient for dentist to apply. At present, to the author’s knowledge, there is no evidence of applicable method to establish stable bonding between PEEK and available dental luting materials.

Self-etching and self-adhesive resin cements have received popularity for luting ceramic, metal and composite indirect restorations, including acidic and hydrophilic monomers, which simultaneously demineralize and infiltrate enamel and dentin. They do not require etching and bonging steps, leading to stable bonding.25 Moreover, resin cement contained reactive fluoride glasses, which would be ionized by absorbing water after light cured.26 The leaked ions, such as calcium, strontium and aluminum, can react with inorganic particles. Consequently, self-etching and self-adhesive cements generally show good adhesion with inorganic oxides or inorganic composites.27,28

In previous report, PEEK composites had been associated with load-bearing implant materials.29 The inorganic particle reinforcement would greatly improve the mechanical behavior of PEEK and significantly decrease the thermal expansion coefficient, making PEEK more suitable for dental application.30,31 Various inorganic materials have been used as reinforcing components and have made up the bulk component of the composites and resin cement, such as silica, zinc oxide, and so on. In addition to reinforcing fillers, barium and strontium are often incorporated to silicon oxide particles, which can add x-ray opacity to facilitate radiological monitoring of PEEK composites in vivo.32 As a widely used material in dentistry, the biocompatibility and biological safety of barium-containing glass filler (BGF) have been proved by various experiment and long-term clinical application. Compounding BGF with PEEK is a physical process that would not change any chemical structure of PEEK. In consequence, the proper biocompatibility of PEEK-BGF composites is foreseeable.

Up to now, there is little information available in the literature about the introduction of inorganic filler into PEEK to promote the bonding ability with dental luting agents in dentistry. The aim of this investigation was to find a simple and practical method for the clinic practice to improve the bond strength of PEEK with resin cement, without changing the chemical structure of PEEK. The hypothesis was that the introduction of BGF provides a stable bond between PEEK composite surface and dental resin cement.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PEEK resin (Changchun Jilin University Super Engineering Plastics Research Co., Ltd, Changchun, China) was supplied as a powder with a melting index of 26 g/10 min and a density of 1.29 g/cm3. The melt flow index of PEEK was measured according to ASTM D1238. BGF particles (SG-25BAG1000, Sukgyung AT Co., Ltd, Seoul, Korea) containing silica 40–50%, barium oxide 15–25%, boron oxide10–15% and aluminum oxide 10–15% were irregular in shape with an aspect ratio near 1 and a mean diameter of 1 μm. The dual-cure resin cements (Dentex dual-cure cement; Sino-Dentex Co., Ltd, Changchun, China) were packed with double syringe.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: BGF and PEEK were dried in oven at 120°C for 3 h and premixed well with pulverizer. Later, they were compounded using a corotating twin-screw (Haake PTW16/25p, Haake Companies, Kansas City, Missouri, USA) extruder with a screw speed of 120 r/min. The temperature profiles of the barrel were 280/320/340/360/360/350°C from the hopper to the die. The extruded PEEK-BGF granules were then dried in an oven at 120°C for 3 h and injected at a barrel temperature of 380°C with a mold temperature of 180°C by injection machine (SZB05714-15g, Shanghai Science and Education Instrument Plant, Shanghai, China). Here, PEEK composites reinforced with 0–40 wt% BGF were prepared by the above injection molding method.

Before the bonding procedure, PEEK and composite disks were embedded in plaster (Dio-Stone, SHG, Xingtai, China) and their surfaces were all homogenously polished with G600 silicon carbide papers. Then the disks were cleaned for 10 min in an ultrasonic water bath (Ultrasonic Cleaner KQ5200DV; Kun Shan Ultrasonic Instruments Co., Ltd, Kunshan, China), air-dried and treated as follows:
Acid etching with hydrofluoric acid (HF, 9.5%, Dentex hydrofluoric acid etching gel; Sino-Dentex Co., Ltd, Changchun China) for 2 min and careful rinsing with water for 1 min.
Silica coating (Dentex Silica, Sino-Dentex Co., Ltd, Changchun, China).
Acid etching with H2SO4 (98%) for 1 min and careful rinsing with water for 1 min.
Polishing with 150 grit silicon carbide papers.Several PEEK and composite disks were acid etched with H2SO4 (98%) for 2 min and careful rinsing with water for 1 min for scanning electron microscopy (SEM) investigation.

sec.title: Surface characterization
sec.p: SEM (FEI Quanta 400 ESEM FEG; FEI Company, Hillsboro, USA) was used to visualize the topography of the samples surface with a magnification of 2000×. Spectra of the sample surface using x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250; Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., Waltham, UK) were determined by Scientific ESCA MKII (VG, East Grinstead, UK), Mg Kα.

sec.title: SBS testing
sec.p: A total of 15 samples of each pretreatment group were bonded as described below. Specimens were cleaned with water and dried with a short air blast for 5s. Acrylic cylinder with an inner diameter of 3.70 mm, an outer diameter of 4.2 mm and a length of 4 mm was pressed onto the composite surface by means of a special device. Dentex composite resin cement catalyst and base were dispensed from the double-push syringe and mixed in a 1:1 ratio. The cement was first filled into the cylinder and then a rod was centrally inserted into the cylinder and loaded. After the cements were light cured from two opposite sides for 20 s with a dental light-emitting diode curing light (ML-III; Mident Industrial Co., Ltd, Henan, China), the samples were carefully removed from the device and stored in water at 37°C for 24 h.

A universal testing machine (AG-1; Shimadzu Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) was used for shear bond strength (SBS) measurements. SBS measurements were performed in subgroups directly after water storage, and the samples were positioned in the sample holder with the composite surface parallel to the loading direction. The loading piston had an aperture configuration in which the cylinder could get through. The load was applied with a crosshead speed of 0.7 mm/min on the outer diameter of the cylinder in a distance of 200 μm from the composite surface. Load at failure was recorded, and shear strength values were calculated.

For the fracture analysis, the deboned area was examined with magnifying glass. Failure was considered either adhesive, if the cement was dislodged from surface, or cohesive, if the fracture occurred only in the cement, PEEK or PEEK-BGF composites.

sec.title: Data presentation and analysis
sec.p: SPSS 16.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, Illinois, USA) was used to carry out the statistical analysis. One-way analysis of variance and t tests were used to determine differences in SBS values between the groups; 5% was set as the level of significance.

sec.title: Surface analysis by XPS
sec.p: To investigate the chemical changes in the sample surfaces with different pretreatments, XPS analysis was conducted and the representative results of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 are listed in Table 1. In pristine PEEK surface, no other element except carbon and oxygen could be found because PEEK is a polymer composed of only C, H and O atoms. After H2SO4 etching, 10.59% sulfur could be detected and oxygen concentration increased from 22.38 to 41.36% as compared to untreated PEEK due to the sulfonation of PEEK surface. With the introduction of BGF particles, both barium and silicon appear in PEEK-BGF40 surface as expected. However, after HF etching, both silicon and barium disappear in XPS spectrum, indicating all BGF particles of PEEK-BGF40 have been etched out. In addition, after silica coating, barium atom cannot be detected in PEEK-BGF40 surface any more, indicating BGF particles have been fully coated by silane coupling agent.

fn.p: PEEK: poly(ether ether ketone); HF: hydrofluoric acid; H2SO4: sulfuric acid; BGF: barium-containing glass filler.

sec.title: Morphology of the sample surface
sec.p: Figure 1 showed surface morphologies of PEEK, PEEK-BGF20 and PEEK-BGF40 after G600 polishing. The polishing procedure led to similar surface roughness. SEM images of PEEK-BGF composites, that is PEEK-BGF20 and PEEK-BGF40, showed that BGF particles are uniformly dispersed in PEEK matrix with an irregular angular shape and no large aggregate of BGF particles could be found. The size of BGF particles was approximately 1 μm (Figure 1(a) to (c)).

caption.p: SEM images of PEEK and PEEK-BGF surface morphology with G600 polishing at a magnification of ×2000 (the bar represents a distance of 10 μm): (a) PEEK, (b) PEEK-BGF20 and (c) PEEK-BGF40. PEEK: poly(ether ether ketone); SEM: scanning electron microscopy; BGF: barium-containing glass filler.

sec.p: Surfaces morphologies of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 after different pretreatments were investigated by SEM. As shown in Figure 2, after etching with HF, the surface of pristine PEEK shows little change compared with the untreated one. However, for PEEK-BGF40, the exposed BGF particles were almost etched out and left a porous surface full of small cavities with a diameter of nearly 1 μm, which is consistent with the results of XPS analysis (Figure 2(a) and (b)). After silica coating, a semitransparent skin was formed on both PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 surfaces (Figure 2(c) and (d)). For H2SO4 etching method, as shown in Figure 2(e) and (f), after 1 min of etching, complex porous network were formed on both pristine PEEK and PEEK-BGF surfaces and large penetrated pores were left with a diameter ranging from 5 μm to 100 μm stochastically. Different from those etched with HF, after H2SO4 treatment, BGF particles were not etched out and could be found in pore walls of PEEK-BGF40 surface. After 2 min of etching, PEEK surface exhibited broken-up structure and likewise PEEK-BGF40 showed many cracks (Figure 2(g) and (h)). Polished with silicon carbide paper (G150), the surface of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 showed wave-like morphologies, much rougher than those polished with G600 (Figure 2(i) and (j)).

caption.p: SEM images of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 modalities after different surface pretreatments at a magnification of ×2000 (the bar represents a distance of 10 μm): PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 etched with hydrofluoric acid (a and b), silica coated (c and d), etched with H2SO4 for 1 min (e and f), etched with H2SO4 for 2 min (g and h) and polished with G150 (i and j). PEEK: poly(ether ether ketone); SEM: scanning electron microscopy; H2SO4: sulfuric acid; BGF: barium-containing glass filler.

sec.title: SBS measurements
sec.p: Mean SBS of PEEK and PEEK-BGF composites was shown in Figure 3. Most pristine PEEK specimens show failure after water storage, indicating its SBS near 0 MPa. After introduction of BGF particles, SBS of PEEK specimens were significantly enhanced and increased with BGF contents. PEEK with 40 wt% BGF reinforcement, that is PEEK-BGF40, showed the SBS value of 10.04 ± 2.38 MPa.

caption.p: Shear bond strength results of PEEK and PEEK-BGF composites polished with G600. PEEK: poly(ether ether ketone); BGF: barium-containing glass filler.

sec.p: Previous reports have indicated that cements could establish stable bonding with resin composites, which was mainly composed of glass fillers, such as BGF.33 Similar results were also obtained here that BGF reinforcements could improve the adhesion between PEEK and resin cement without complex treatments or breaking the surface structure. To investigate the effects of BGF introduction and to further improve the adhesion between PEEK and resin cement, some surface treatments were separately conducted using HF, H2SO4, silica coating or simple polishing with a rougher sand paper (G150).

The results of mean SBS of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 with different pretreatment are presented in Figure 4. HF treatment cannot improve the adhesion to pristine PEEK and even decreased SBS value of PEEK composites. In contrast, the SBS of PEEK-BGF40 after HF etching was 3.26 ± 1.23 MPa, which has been decreased by 67.54% compared with PEEK-BGF40 without any pretreatment (p < 0.05). It was well known that PEEK could not be damaged by any solvents except for concentrated H2SO4.1 So, HF could only etched out exposed BGF particles without changing PEEK bonding property, which has been proved by XPS and SEM characterizations. It is clear that BGF fillings play a key role in improving the adhesive property of PEEK. Such improvement could be owing to (1) reaction between BGF and resin cement and (2) the improvement of superficial energy and wettability.

caption.p: Bar chart representation of shear bond tests.

sec.p: Silica coating was able to establish an adhesion to PEEK surface with the bond strength of 4.39 ± 1.17 MPa, whereas it decreased the adhesion to PEEK-BGF40 by 23.26% with the bond strength of 7.71 ± 1.57 MPa (p < 0.05). After silica coating, the coupling agent could penetrate into the surface structure of PEEK and PEEK-BGF composites. The coupling agent could hydrolyze to silanols and further condense and deposit, which then form a continuous siloxane film on the surface.34 Chemically, silane coupling agents could copolymerize with the carbon–carbon double bonds of resin cement monomers. As a result, the silica coating was helpful to adhesion of PEEK to cement with the bond strength of 4.39 ± 1.17 MPa. This result is in agreement with previously published results.9 However, due to the fact that the coupling agent could obstruct the reaction between BGF and resin cement concluded from XPS and SEM analyses, the bond strength between silica-coating PEEK-BGF40 and resin cement decreased to 7.71 ± 1.57 MPa (p < 0.05), which is about 23% decrease when compared with untreated one.35

After 98% H2SO4 etching, PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 showed high SBS of 17.77 ± 2.86 MPa and 19.70 ± 3.12 MPa, respectively (p < 0.05). H2SO4 etching led to a highly porous and permeable surface structure of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40, which would facilitate the cement penetration. These changes formed stable micromechanical interlocking between PEEK and resin cement. In addition, H2SO4 etching process resulted in the sulfonation of PEEK surface, as discussed in XPS analysis (Table 1), which could further react and form chemical linkage with resin cement. However, owing to the fact that H2SO4 is a highly corrosive and flowable liquid, it makes the etching process uncontrollable and hard to be used under clinical conditions.9 After 2 min of H2SO4 etching, obvious breakages appear in PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 surface confirmed by SEM measurements (Figure 2).

G150 polishing treatment could also enhance SBS values of PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 to 6.36 ± 1.95 MPa and 19.73 ± 4.30 MPa, respectively, much higher than G600 polishing treatment (p < 0.05). In addition to above chemical treatments, simple physical methods to make a rough surface are often used to improve surface adhesion. After polished with G150, PEEK-BGF40 showed a similar SBS value with H2SO4-etched ones (p > 0.05) and much higher than those polished with G600 due to its much rougher surface (Figure 2), indicating that the bonding strength could also be improved by micromechanical interlocking.36 Consequently, PEEK-BGF composites with a rough surface may be a good choice to substitute traditional etching method for improving the adhesion between PEEK and resin cement.

sec.title: Failure mode
sec.p: Table 2 shows the results of the fracture analysis. H2SO4-etched PEEK and PEEK-BGF40 exhibited higher percentage of cohesive failures (53 and 67%, respectively), and PEEK-BGF40 polished with G150 exhibit 20% of cohesive failures. No cohesive failures appeared in other groups.

caption.p: Fracture modes of the different treatment (percentage; number of samples in parentheses).

fn.p: PEEK: poly(ether ether ketone); H2SO4: sulfuric acid; BGF: barium-containing glass filler; HF: hydrofluoric acid.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Various amounts of BGF-reinforced PEEK composites were prepared by twin screw, and BGF particles are well dispersed in PEEK matrix, which are confirmed by the SEM results. The SBS between PEEK and resin cement is dramatically increased by BGF reinforcement. Furthermore, after simple polishing, a SBS value of 19.73 ± 4.30 MPa for PEEK-BGF40 composite could be obtained, with no statistical difference to H2SO4 etching groups. HF etching and silica-coating treatment revealed that the enhanced SBS is due to BGF filling. It was demonstrated that BGF-reinforced PEEK can establish a stable high bond strength with dental adhesive, without complex treatments.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The help of the SINO-DENTEX Co., Ltd was greatly appreciated.
